WRITING.TITLE: Adult self harmers
WRITING.TEXT: There is this stigma and misconception about self harm that only teenagers/ young people engage in self injury behaviours. In my opinion it's very detrimental. It makes it so much harder for anyone older than that to seek help because it seems as if self harm is not something 'an adult would do'. Not only that: it's also detrimental to young people/teenagers who self harm because by attributing self injury behaviour mainly to young age we make it sound like something that people will grow out of. As much as in some cases it is indeed the case - not in all. And concentrating on the hope that somebody will simply without any treatment grow out of it by himself/herself is basically preventing help that could be provided if the problem was tackled straight away. By the time it is realized that a person isn't growing out of it despite the time passing by the problem can already grow into much bigger proportions and recovery will be more difficult, if still possible at all. Another thing worth mentioning is that if a problem is perceived as only 'young people problem' it implies that it has something to do with immaturity. And again: as much as it can be the case - it's not always the case. Assuming someone hurts themselves because of being immature is hurtful to self harmers of any age making people avoid seeking help and feeling even worse about themselves than they already are. Another thing that is hurtful when it comes to self harm and age is that there is not enough mental health resources directed at adults who self harm. In terms of statistics there is definitely more young people self harming than there is older people. But a big but is that adults who do indeed engage in self injury tend to do more damage and their sh behaviours are often more dangerous and because of all the age social stigma I mentioned above - they seek help less often. I am wondering what you Guys think about it...? Any thoughts? Are you an adult who self harms and feel this way? Would you like to share your feeling on the subject? Thank you all for reading my post.

It sounds like you really are in pain... . How about have a little think about what is it exactly that self harm is giving you? I mean: every incident of self harm fulfils for a person some psychological need or needs. I'll give you some examples. Self harm can for example fulfil: need to express pain when words just dont seem enough ; need to draw attention to the person who might feel invisible, ignored, not cared for, not loved, lonely, or wants someone to offer help ; need to punish oneself due to underlying feelings of self blame, self hatres, guilt ; need to relief tension and accumulated pressure ; need to feel something when one feels numb ; need to distract oneself from something else ........ etc. etc. etc. So basically what Im asking is what psychological need does sh fulfiled for you the first two times you have done it...? It may be more than one. The needs may not be equally strong.. for example you may feel that mainly it was due to one need but in some smaller degree also due to another need. Once you identify the need/s that you are trying to fulfil you can start thinking of how else instead of sh you could possible fulfil this need. You can think about better and healthier options perhaps. Of course the main thing is you DO NOT attempt to kill yourself. But if that is your main issue right now, suicidal thoughts/plans then pleaseeee seek help. There IS help out there. There are free helplines of all sorts, there are therapists, hospitals, support houses, medication, self soothing tactics, you can reach out to someone you trust... I know it all feels scary at first. But it is worth it if you can only make it through the bad times until these are over... Often it really is about postponing the worst scenarios and just making it through... and once on the other end everything fills so worth it I guess and you probably wont understand any more why you thought of such drastic measures. I hope that helps at least tiny bit... .

There are no safe overdose limits. Trust me. Don't believe anything you find on the internet or elsewhere about safe/non fatal overdose amounts/cases. The effects of od on individual body cannot be predicted even by the doctors. Yes, there are likelihoods - some amount of od may be less or more likely to kill but these likelihoods are, as the name suggests, not guarantees. There ARE exceptions. How individuals body will react to a particular overdose depends on more aspects than you can think of. I'll name few of them, I'll use "drug" as medicine: type of drug, amount of drug, the form of medicine (tablets, what type of tablets, short/long realised ones, intravenous or oral or other), general health of the individual, what medicine they're on and how much, past medical history, weight, age, how much and what and when they ate last, hydration levels, undiagnosed conditions they may not be aware of, whether it's a staggered overdose or not, what's the person's body tolerance for particular type of drug if any, how fast they get help, if they are actually going to get the right treatment for this particular overdose in time, what medical measures actually exist to help in particular od - if any, if the symptoms are managed well, previous condition of someones body ex liver kidney etc etc, even if they had a good night sleep and are rested and have the strength to cope with pressure put on the body by od or not..... And others. Let me just say: no matter how carefully you research the safe amount to od on there is always a chance you will not find it safe in your case. You may even do it few times and it ended up ok... But the next time it may not.

You can go to a and e and be seen by a doctor. The a and e doctor will request for you to be seen there in a and e by someone from psych team. A person with mental health training from psych team will then come (sooner or later) and have a conversation with you about the reasons you are there and your background and any other relevant information like medications diagnosis family history etc. Obviously they will ask you if you are suicidal as well as questions relating to that. They will ask about delusions/hallucinations/voices etc. They will ask about thoughts of harming yourself or others. If they admit you and in what way (voluntarily or section) will depend on symptoms you experience, the insight you have into your issues as well as things like social/family situation etc etc etc. Basically many factors matter. If they deem you require psychiatric admission for either purpose of diagnosis or purpose of safe guarding etc then they will arrange that and you may have to wait for a while for them to do so (even few days in hospital sometimes). Obviously they will also decide what type of ward you may be admitted to.
